narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Simplex algorithm, gradient descent, KKT conditions, etc.
Optimization, proofs, computational complexity theory

optimization and computation skills. I know this is like the most no brain answer, but i really thought it was cool to get the linear algebra knowledge, then moving on to some of the methods we are familiar with in other contexts (see: GD, simplex method) and develop those thoroughly, and ending with discussion on complexity and algorithms. This was very cool
none

I don't know - the PSets were almost orthogonal to the lectures, and the final "optional" assignment to implement the simplex method for solving LPs and stochastic gradient descent was not instructive whatsoever.
Got a decent math-oriented overview of a few different types of optimization techniques.
Proofs behind gradient descent and other optimisation algorithms, linear programming, etc.
We learned about linear programming, KKT conditions and other concepts relevant to convex optimization, and a bit about complexity theory.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor clearly didn't care much about the course -- she missed 6 lectures (out of 22) and for many didn't even upload a recorded lecture to replace missing class. In class, she often didn't elaborate on proofs and refused to answer questions about the homework because she hadn't even looked at the homework questions, instead ripping them off from other iterations of the class. For these eight 2-question psets, she only had her grader check one problem, so any mistake (even a small computational mistake) on a single problem on a single pset could utterly tank your grade as this class is 100% psets. Overall, I've taken several bad courses at Yale, but never a course where I felt the instructor cared less about the material or the students.

i guess it was freaky to have 7 homework problems (literally 7 problems, not 7 psets) dictate the whole grade and i hope this will turn out fine (fingers crossed). Strength is in the material, great stuff is being learnt from some of the most classic textbooks in the subject, such as the boyd book and the lunenberger and ye.
none

The strengths of this class are that the grade is only based on PSets and that the professor's notes are neat. The weaknesses of this course stems from the professor's apathy - she frequently cancelled classes for appointments, never gave assignments related to her lectures, and gave a final "optional" assignment to implement the simplex method and stochastic gradient descent which nobody wanted to do. Further, only one problem was graded on each PSet, and no solutions were ever provided. This class could be improved by having a professor who teaches content related to what's on her assignments and desires to teach every day.
The homework wasn't too bad, there were no tests--class was relatively laid back. I kind of wished it had covered more content, though.

This course was pretty bad. The first couple weeks had interesting material, but after that it was pretty hard to follow. Zoom lectures were really boring, the material got harder and the psets started diverging from what was taught in class, and by the end of it I had no idea what we were learning. Psets were manageable with the TAs help, but I cant say I learned a lot of stuff that I will remember. There was only 1 hour of office hours once a week, and it was impossible to get help outside of that. The TA was super helpful, but the professor refused to hold office hours herself, simply assigned psets from the previous professor without even reading them, and refused to answer any questions about psets.

While Professor Gilbert's lectures were very clear, I don't feel like I had enough opportunity to practice the material because the problem sets were too short and infrequently assigned (we didn't have homework for around three weeks at the end of the semester). Although I tried to remedy this problem by doing exercises and textbook readings on my own, it was difficult to do so because there was no assigned reading and we jumped around a lot between topics. Also, there were several days where Professor Gilbert canceled lecture or posted lecture notes without a recorded video because she had a scheduling conflict. While this has been a challenging semester because of COVID, and I understand there are ways in which it might have been particularly difficult for instructors, it was a bit disheartening to see this lack of dedication because teaching is ultimately part of a professor's job description, and college courses are still expensive during a pandemic.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: none
The Zoom lectures were bad because of the professor, not the infrastructure.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: definitely take this and take sekhar's 432 when he starts offering it next spring i think this would be such a good set of skills to have
yes

No - I don't think I really learned anything since the PSets had nothing to do with the lectures and I didn't see any point in trying to engage with the material if the professor didn't really want to teach all the time.
If you're into math/cs/stats and enjoy linear algebra, it's a nice course that isn't too stressful.

Not really! Maybe itll be better in person, but over zoom it was really hard to follow. The lectures were completely separate from the psets and the professor absolutely refused to provide any help on the psets.

I'm not sure. On one hand, the material is probably good to know if you're thinking of going into statistics or machine learning, but on the other hand, I don't think I would have gotten anything out of the course that I wouldn't have gotten from the publicly available notes on Professor Spielman's website, since Professor Gilbert followed his notes to a tee (but covered slightly less material). Also, the content overlaps to some extent with the computer science department's algorithms course, so I would probably recommend taking that course instead and learning the convex programming material, which is easier, independently or through Professor Spielman's lecture notes.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: also lectures were recorded
notes
Optimization was a combination of live virtual lectures and uploaded notes.
Virtual office hours with the TA.
